newsitem.title: USA: USDA May 12 world grain highlights.
newsitem.headline: USDA May 12 world grain highlights.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Monday lowered its estimate for the 1996/97 Argentina soybean crop to 12.40 million tonnes due to dry weather, and decreased its forecast for Brazil soybean production to 26.50 million tonnes.
In its May world supply/demand report, USDA also sharply increased its export estimate for Brazil soybeans to 6.50 million tonnes, reflecting increased shipments to Europe and Asia.
USDA also significantly lowered its Argentine soybean export forecast to 950,000 tonnes, down from 1.90 million tonnes estimated last month.

USDA increased its estimate for China soybean production to 13.50 million tonnes and a senior USDA analyst said Chinese soybean production next year is likely to be even bigger due to increased plantings.
China corn exports in 1996/97 were left unchanged at 2.50 million tonnes, and were lowered to 2.00 million in 1997/98 due to a lower corn production estimate of 122 million tonnes.
Wheat production in all major exporting countries was estimated to be down in 1997/98, but with the large carryin stocks from 1996/97, exports were expected to stay strong.

Australia wheat exports in 1996/97 were raised for the fifth month in a row to 19.00 million tonnes, but were lowered to 14.00 million tonnes for 1997/98. Canada wheat exports in 1996/97 were left unchanged at 18 million tonnes but were raised to 19.00 million tonnes in 1997/98.
World grain crops were projected to total 1,854.61 million tonnes in 1997/98, slightly below the 1996/97 level of 1,858.55 million tonnes.
1997/98 world wheat production was pegged at 578.44 million tonnes, oilseeds at 273.00 million tonnes, coarse grains at 898.87 million, rice at 377.31 million, and cotton at 87.50 million bales.
